BASEBALL TO ORGANIZE FEB. 1

MUSICIANS STILL NEED MEN

FIRST SENIOR BENEFIT JAN. 21

MOVING SPECIMENS BIG TASK

Schedule for Black and Blue Nine Comprehensive —Work on Team to Begin First of Next Month.

Success of Clubs Depends on Showing of
Students From Now On--Tenors
Badly Needed for Glee Club.

1916 Hullabaloo Committee Plan Big
Hopkins Night at Performance of
"Rolling Stones" Tickets
Selling Rapidly.

Transportation of Geology Department
to Homewood Offers Tremendous
Problem—Over 1,000,000 Specimens to Be Handled.

The baseball schedule, as recently
announced by Manager Chalmers,
includes some of the best teams in
the East. Hopkins has a task before
it to hold its own against such nines
as Yale, Harvard and Holy Cross,
but from the wealth of material
available the Black and Blue should
have a team that will be able to
make a very creditable showing
against any college.
The season will open April I,
With Gettysburg College, at Gettysburg. The next week Hopkins will
Play Washington College at Homewood. On April 15 the team will
Journey to Washington to play the
strong Georgetown team, and the
five contests following this game
will be at home. April 20 and 21
will see the Hopkins team in action
against Yale and Harvard. On account of the calibre of the Yale and
Harvard teams, and because of the
fact that many graduates of the
• two colleges live in Baltimore, a
large crowd may be expected at
Homewood on these two days.
About the first of February an
organization meeting will be held
and practice will be started immediately. Only two regulars, Sutton
and Butler, were lost from last
Year's team, and with no first-string
men oh the disqualified list and several promising new players in the
Medical School and in the freshmen
Class, the prospects for a fast nine
are exceedingly bright.
The schedule follows:
April 1—Gettysburg at Gettysburg..
April 8—Washington College at
Homewood.
April i5—Georgetown at Georgetown.
April 20—Yale at Homewood.
April 2I —Harvard at Homewood.
April 26—Holy Cross at Homewood.
April 29—M. A. C. at Homewood.
May 6—Swarthmore at 'HomeWood
May 13—Navy at Annapolis.
May 20—St. John's at Homewood.

Rehearsals of the Glee and Mandolin Clubs were held during the
holidays, and the director reports
that with a week or two more in
which to do the finishing work, the
musicians will be in shape to give
concerts. The Glee Club has been
rather seriously hampered in its
work by a decided lack of candidates for the tenor section. If men
come out for the positions in question within the next few days, the
work on the regular program will
be completed in two or three rehearsals and the club will begin to
devote some of its time to working
up several numbers somewhat out
of the ordinary run of music used
by Hopkins singers. All depends
on the tenor section.
The Instrumental Club will feature the mandolin-guitar-banjo section this year to a greater degree
than that worked up to in former
years. Men are still needed for
all positions on the club and a call
has been issued by the director for
instrumentalists of any kind. Rehearsals are held regularly on Friday nights, and from now on extra
work will be done at odd times during the week.
Several special acts are being
tried, and, if successful, will be featured on the program. The music,
both vocal and instrumental, is all
new and includes a number of
novelties which are expected to
make a hit with Baltimore audiences. The clubs only need a few
more men to complete their equipment for a big success.
The McCoy Hall concert and
dance, which is scheduled for the
evening of February 25, will be
made especially attractive in order
to enlist the support of more alumni
and friends of the University. Since
the attendance of undergraduate
students not members of the clubs
has been nominal in past years, an
effort to make the concert much
more of a student affair will be
made. Tickets will be sold to undergraduates at reduced rates, according to a plan, details of which
will be given out at the time tickets
are put on sale.
The success of the clubs now depends on the support given them by
Hopkins men. The schedule is
nearly completed, work on the music has reached the fininshing-off
stage and final preparations will
be finished in a short time if the
necessary men lend their support.
It is a difficult thing to produce
well - balanced musical clubs at
Johns Hopkins, but the director re-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 10, 1915.

DR. WELCH BACK FROM CHINA

LACROSSE MEN HARD AT WORK

Hopkins Pathologist Reports on Conditions of Medicinal Study in Far East.
Japan Friendly Toward U. S.

Squad of 40 Candidates Practicing Regularly in the Cage—Prospects for
Championship Twelve
Very Bright.

Dr. William H. Welch, dean of
the Johns Hopkins Medical School,
has just returned to Baltimore after a trip to China, which he undertook last summer as a representative of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Dr. Welch left on June 30. He
spent three weeks in the Hawaiian
Islands and five weeks in Yokohama, Japan; visited Pekin and
Moukton and went up the Yangtse
River beyond Hamktow.
The chief purpose of Dr. Welch's
expedition was to investigate medical education in China, and to introduce some of the medical ideas
of the Occidentals. As a result of
the visit, Dr. Welch will make extensive recommendations tending to
improve the medical ideas of the
country through the China Medical Board, of which he is a member.
The report to this board has not
as yet been made. Dr. Welch said
that the work to be taken in hand
immediately would be the enlarging
of the Union Medical School in
Pekin and the possible establishment
of another school, probably in
Shanghai.
Dr. Welch, when interviewed,
stated that the opportunities for
medical education in China are very
great, but that there are serious
drawbacks, such as the difficulties
met in locating the schools, lack of
funds wherewith to pay for the services of good doctors, and inability
to acquire good men without paying
good salaries.
•
Dr. Welch also expressed himself
in regard to the political situation
in China. He is of the opinion that
China is not so much of a republic
as a military despotism, and thinks
that the sentiment of the country
is apparently opposed to the republican form.
As regards the relations of the
United States with Japan, Dr.
Welch believes that there is nothing
which need at any time in the future cause a clash between the two
countries. At the same time, however, he stated that the Japanese are
a proud people, who are deter •
mined that they shall be accepted
on the same basis on which the
other great nations of the world are
accepted.
Now that Japan has been cut off
from its medical relations with Germany, Dr. Welch thinks many are
coming to this country to study
medicine. Moreover, the Japanese
have developed the study of medicine within their own land to such
a point that we are able to learn
from them.
This has been the first time since
his connection with Hopkins that
Dr. Welch has not been at the University for the opening of the academic year.

With the holiday season a thing
of the past, the lacrosse squad has
now settled down to the hard work
that is ahead in order to develop
a championship 1916 team.
Several practices were held in
the cage during the Christmas holidays. However, it is realized that
with only about two months left to
round out the team there is much
hard work ahead for the members
of the squad. Captain Paul Sutton especially emphasizes the need
of defensive material. The team
will be materially weakened in this
department this season through the
loss of John Huck. With this in
mind, the coaches are watching a
number of new men who are showing particularly good form for this
position.
Practices are now held daily.
Coach Rainey Wolfe heretofore has
been rather lax with the men in
regard to attendance, but now he
wants it known that it is imperative that all men who are out for
the team must report more regularly, especially on Wednesday and
Saturday, when the entire squad
works out in the cage.
Scrimmages are also a feature of
the practices. The squad is divided
into two teams, with the lineup
changed from time to time, in order
to give the men a better chance to
try out the various positions.
A contemplation of this season's
material shows prospects for a lacrosse team that will compare with
last year's championship team to
be very bright. The squad is composed of about forty men and contains ten of the twelve members ofthe 1915 team. The two players
who were lost are John Huck and
Toni Troxell, two of the best lacrosse players who ever represented
the Black and Blue. The coaches
realize that they have a hard task
before them in filling the places of
these former stars, but are relying
on last year's substitutes and a number of new players on the squad
who entered the University this
year from City College and Polytechnic Institute to fill the open
gaps.
Probably the most promising new
member of the squad is Arthur
Knipp, an uncle of Johnny Knipp,
who has returned to the University this year in order to take certain engineering courses. Some
years ago, Mr. Knipp was a star
member of Hopkins teams, playing
on the 'Varsity for three successive
years. He is still eligible by the
rules of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
League to play another year for the
Black and Blue.
The coaches also emphasize the
fact that although only two vacancies appear this year, there are at
all times twelve positions to be contested for, and the tiew men have

JUNIORS AND SENIORS HARD
AT WORK ON COMING DEBATE

Preparations for the inter-class
debate are being made by both the
Junior and Senior teams, and there
is every indication that the contest
of January 28 will be a hard-fought
and interesting one.
Owing to the fact that preparations for the 'Varsity triangle debates have not as yet been completed, the class debaters did no
work whatever previous to or during the Christmas holidays. The
men on both teams were anxious
to have the same subject for the
inter-class as for the University
debates in order that a great
deal of extra work might be saved
and the contests of next spring adequately prepared for. As further
delay is now impossible, however,
the work of preparation has been
activly entered upon, and Hopkins
is hoping that the question submitted by her council will meet
with the approval of Virginia and
North Carolina.
The subject of the Junior-Senior
debate, "Resolved, that for state legislatures a unicameral is preferable
to a bicameral system," is one that
has of late been discussed by many
writers on political subjects, and
that should prove of particular interest to the members of the first
undergraduate class in political science in the University.
Positions on the two teams were
not as closely contested this year as
is usually the case, owing to the fact
that the tryouts were held immediately before the Christmas examinations. The members of the Junior team, which will champion the
affirmative of the question, are A. A.
Steinbach, chairman; A. A. Weech
and Randolph Smith, while the Senior debaters are T. J. Tingley, chairman; G. Franklin Ludington and
Harrison C. Coffin. Mr. C. Whitford McDowell is the Senior alternate, while the Junior alternate and
advisors for both teams will be
chosen in the immediate future.

LECTURES ON "CITY PLANNING"

FIFTH REGIMENT MEET FEB. 12

Prof. Fairclough, of Stanford, Talks to
Archaeological Society on Building
of Ancient Cities of Rome.

Hotly Contested Races Expected—Meeting of Athletic Association Called to
Ratify Spring Schedule and
Arrange Meet.

The local society of the Archeological Institute of America held
its first meeting of the year on
January 3, in McCoy Hall, at which
time an illustrated lecture was given
by Prof. H. Rushton Fairclough,
formerly a director in the American
Academy at Rome and now a
member of the faculty of Stanford
University. Professor Faircloug-h's
topic, "City Planning in Ancient
Rome," was in a way a sequel to
his former lecture given here on
the three beautiful capitals of the
world—Athens, Rome and Washington.
"City planning," he said, "is not
a new development; the first public
basilica having been built in 185 B.
C., and the first arch in 121 B. C.
But though Rome had its forum
before the time of Cesar, the first
efforts toward a well-planned city
and civic center originated with
him. He sought to make the forum
more symmetrical and to enlarge it
for the demands which would be
placed upon it as the chief public
place of the imperial city. A walled
city in the midst of the activities of
the city proper, the forum was a
place set apart suitable for special
functions, where the orators spoke,
from which the emperors sent forth
the generals and governors of the
empire, and where many religious
celebrations were held.
"Cxsar also first attempted the
beautification of the Campus Martins and devoted himself to the construction of such massive public
structures as the Circus Maximus
and the Basilica Julia. The system
of parks and public places thus inaugurated was advanced by the succeeding emperors, notably Augustus, Vespasian, Nerva and Trajan."
Professor Fairclough closed his
lecture by calling attention to the
large part classical architecture has
played in America's model city of
the Panama-Pacific Exposition. Its
walled effect, with courts dominated
by a public building, is reminiscent
of the forums, while a number of
the palaces are reproductions of the
Roman Thermae. Much of the
charm of the exposition, indeed, was
due, he said, to the combination of
all the arts in the true classical
spirit.

A meeting of the Athletic Association has been called for this afternoon at 5 o'clock, in the Trophy
Room. Among the most important
matters to be brought up during
the meeting will be the ratification
of the spring schedule and the completion of the plans for the Hopkins-Fifth Regiment track meet.
The Fifth Regiment meet is
scheduled to begin at 8 o'clock on
the evening of Saturday, February
12. This will be the eleventh annual track meet to be held under
the joint auspices of the Fifth
Regiment and the Johns Hopkins
University, and is certain to be hotly
contested. A number of very
brilliant relay races are promised
between teams representing some
of the biggest colleges in the country, as well as the Hopkins-Virginia
relay race, which is the main event
each year.
This meet has been arranged by
a joint committee composed of three
members from both the Fifth Regiment and the University, and which
has for its chairman Lieut.-Col.
Washington Bowie, Jr.
As has been the custom in past
years, undergraduate students will
act as ushers.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 10, 1915.
The Hullabaloo Benefit.

Friday night, January, 21, will be
the time for every Hopkins man to
do his part toward the publication
of the 1916 Hullabaloo.
The opinion seems to prevail
among under-classmen generally
that the Ht,illabaloo is the affair of
the Senior Class alone, that somehow
or other it is the business of two or
three editors to create, compile, finance and publish the book that is to
represent the entire University,.and
that is to be enjoyed by every
undergraduate. As a matter of fact,
every man at Hopkins ought to take
a personal interest in the Senior annual. It is not the record of the
accomplishments of the graduating
class alone: it is typical of the University as a whole. There is no
Hopkins activity, from football to
chess, that is not given its adequate
place and reCorded all due honor between its covers. The Hullabaloo is
typical of Hopkins life and of Hopkins men.
The Board this year has done
everything in its power to make the
book the best that has ever been
issued by a Hopkins graduating
class. They have secured the services of the ablest engravers in the

country, and the photographic work
is of the highest quality. Advance
indications are to the effect that the
1916 book will be the "best ever."
But the Board can only create a
good Hullabaloo; they can not make
it a success. That is the manifest
duty of every man at the University.
There is no reason why the Hopkins annual should not occupy a
position among • the best college
yearbooks published in the country.
It should be a matter of pride with
Hopkins men to make it occupy
such a position.
The 1916 benefit will be held Friday night, January 21, at Ford's.
Don't give up too early in your attempt to sell the Senior tickets. And
by all means be on hand Friday
night to make it a real Hopkins
night, and not a hopeless "flareback."
SENIORS ELECT DR. LATANE
HONORARY CLASS PRESIDENT

At a meeting of the Class of 1916,
held on Wednesday at i P. M., in
Room I I, Dr. John Holladay Latane, professor of history of the
University faculty, was elected honorary president of the seniors. A
large number of candidates were
nominated for the position, and
after some elimination, Dr. Latane
was chosen.
An address concerning the coming senior benefit at "Rolling
Stones," on the night of January
21, was made by Mr. McDowell,
the chairman of the benefit committee, who urged the members of the
class to do their best to make the
affair a success and so to insure.
the success of their Hullabaloo.
WORK ON CIVIL ENGINEERING
BUILDING WELL UNDER WAY

In spite of the bad weather, considerable progress has been made
on the new Civil Engineering Building at Homewood during the holidays. The excavation has been
completed and the concrete foundations and the lower brick walls
are now being laid.
The contract calls for the completion of the building by August 15,
and unless the winter is extremely
severe it should be finished on time.
The style of the new building will
be colonial, thus conforming with
the other structures. In appearance it will be very much like the
present Electrical and Mechanical
Building, which it will face. A
striking difference, however, will
be found in the part corresponding
to Machinery Hall and in the wings.
In their place a large lecture room
or auditorium will be built in the
center of the back. The remainder
of the building will closely follow
in general details the present one.

1915.

U. S. TO CONDUCT STUDENT CAMP
College Men Have Opportunity to Learn
Military Details at Low Cost at
Fort Oglethorpe, Ga.

A student camp, which will be
open to college students, will begin
its season at Fort Oglethorpe, Ga.,
on July 5, 1916. It will be conducted by the Eastern Department
of the United States Army.
Any student between the ages
of eighteen and thirty, who is five
feet four inches high, having eyesight normal or corrected by glasses
to admit of target practice, may, if
his application blank is accepted,
receive four weeks' training in the
camp in the fundamental education
of an officer, including rifle practice.
Special opportunities will be offered
for training in various branches of
the service—cavalry, artillery, engineers, signal corps and first aid.
The expense for the four weeks
will be thirty dollars and will completely cover board, camp expenses
and ammunition expended. The
student will also be expected to provide his clothing, which can be secured at camp the government
will furnish ordnance, blankets, etc.
The Young Men's Christian Association will provide tables, chairs,
washing material, etc.
Fort Oglethorpe is near Chattanooga, Tenn., and has large drill
grounds, running water, electric
lights and ample space in which
to store trunks and suitcases containing civilian clothes.
Application blanks and any information may be had by applyng to
"Officer in Charge, Southern Military Training Camp, Governors
Island, N. Y."
High Honor for Dr. Lovejoy.

Dr. A. 0: Lovejoy, of the University faculty of philosophy, was
recently elected president of the
American Philosophical Association.
Before he came to Hopkins, Dr.
Lovejoy was professor of philosophy at Leland Stanford and at the
University of Missouri. He has
done ninth important work on
eighteenth century philosophy, the
history of the theory of evolution,
relation of Kant's philosophy to the
earlier schools, and the idea of
energy in primitive religion and
magic.
Dr. Lovejoy was vice-president
of the society in 1909, and president
of the Western Philosophical Association in 19o8, but this is the first
time that a Hopkins man has had
the distinction of being president
of the American Philosophical Association.
"What time have you?"
"Five o'clock."
"But my watch says six."
"But mine must be right. I've
looked at it three times, and it said
five each time." — Harvard Lampoon.

WITH THE COLLEGE WITS
That Boston Tea Party.

"Did I hear you say lemon ?"
purred the pouring bud.
"N-no, I never use slang," Horace replied, as he stepped on the foot
of a lady behind him.
"Cream, then ?" guessed the
hostess.
"Thank you—I beg your pardon
p-please excuse me—thank—" he
stammered, speaking before and behind at the same time. So she
gave him tea without cream. He
thought he had asked for cream, because he hated tea without it; but
what could he do? He took it, and
promptly flipped the spoon on the
floor: . She offered him another one,
but he insisted on retrieving his
own—to hide his confusion. He
stooped to pick it up, and poured
hot tea on a slender silk-clad ankle
in his efforts.
"Oh, I beg your—." As he got
up, his head hit the table. A pile
of sandwiches slid from the plate
to the carpet, cascading over his
neck. This was too much. He
staggered to his feet.
"Really, I do beg—." But she was
not looking at him. Thoroughly
routed, he grasped a cake, and
buried his thumb in the soft raspberry jam which capped it. Desperation seized him. He dragged
his handkerchief from his pocket;
as it came out, it was accompanied
by
office call

door bearing his personal effects
upon a tray. But the family did not
exclude him from their home.
Henceforth they invited him to entertain the company. — Harvard

against possible trouble. As it
proved, the operation was extremely
Dr. French is now recovering
ra.pidly, and, to the satisfaction of
his mans' friends among both the
faculty and the student body, expects to return to the University
some time during the present week.

Schedule for Black and Blue Nine Comprehensive —Work on Team to Begin First of Next Month.

Success of Clubs Depends on Showing of
Students From Now On--Tenors
Badly Needed for Glee Club.

1916 Hullabaloo Committee Plan Big
Hopkins Night at Performance of

Selling Rapidly.

to Homewood Offers Tremendous

The baseball schedule, as recently
announced by Manager Chalmers,
includes some of the best teams in
the East. Hopkins has a task before
it to hold its own against such nines
as Yale, Harvard and Holy Cross,
but from the wealth of material
available the Black and Blue should
have a team that will be able to
make a very creditable showing
against any college.
The season will open April I,
With Gettysburg College, at Gettysburg. The next week Hopkins will
Play Washington College at Homewood. On April 15 the team will
Journey to Washington to play the
strong Georgetown team, and the
five contests following this game
will be at home. April 20 and 21
will see the Hopkins team in action
against Yale and Harvard. On account of the calibre of the Yale and
Harvard teams, and because of the
fact that many graduates of the
• two colleges live in Baltimore, a
large crowd may be expected at
Homewood on these two days.
About the first of February an
organization meeting will be held
and practice will be started immediately. Only two regulars, Sutton
and Butler, were lost from last
Year's team, and with no first-string
men oh the disqualified list and several promising new players in the
Medical School and in the freshmen
Class, the prospects for a fast nine
are exceedingly bright.
The schedule follows:
April 1—Gettysburg at Gettysburg..
April 8—Washington College at
Homewood.
April i5—Georgetown at Georgetown.
April 20—Yale at Homewood.
April 2I —Harvard at Homewood.
April 26—Holy Cross at Homewood.
April 29—M. A. C. at Homewood.
May 6—Swarthmore at 'HomeWood
May 13—Navy at Annapolis.
May 20—St. John's at Homewood.

Rehearsals of the Glee and Mandolin Clubs were held during the
holidays, and the director reports
that with a week or two more in
which to do the finishing work, the
musicians will be in shape to give
concerts. The Glee Club has been
rather seriously hampered in its
work by a decided lack of candidates for the tenor section. If men
come out for the positions in question within the next few days, the
work on the regular program will
be completed in two or three rehearsals and the club will begin to
devote some of its time to working
up several numbers somewhat out
of the ordinary run of music used
by Hopkins singers. All depends
on the tenor section.
The Instrumental Club will feature the mandolin-guitar-banjo section this year to a greater degree
than that worked up to in former
years. Men are still needed for
all positions on the club and a call
has been issued by the director for
instrumentalists of any kind. Rehearsals are held regularly on Friday nights, and from now on extra
work will be done at odd times during the week.
Several special acts are being
tried, and, if successful, will be featured on the program. The music,
both vocal and instrumental, is all
new and includes a number of
novelties which are expected to
make a hit with Baltimore audiences. The clubs only need a few
more men to complete their equipment for a big success.
The McCoy Hall concert and
dance, which is scheduled for the
evening of February 25, will be
made especially attractive in order
to enlist the support of more alumni
and friends of the University. Since
the attendance of undergraduate
students not members of the clubs
has been nominal in past years, an
effort to make the concert much
more of a student affair will be
made. Tickets will be sold to undergraduates at reduced rates, according to a plan, details of which
will be given out at the time tickets
are put on sale.
The success of the clubs now depends on the support given them by
Hopkins men. The schedule is
nearly completed, work on the music has reached the fininshing-off
stage and final preparations will
be finished in a short time if the
necessary men lend their support.
It is a difficult thing to produce
well - balanced musical clubs at

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 10, 1915.

DR. WELCH BACK FROM CHINA

LACROSSE MEN HARD AT WORK

Hopkins Pathologist Reports on Conditions of Medicinal Study in Far East.
Japan Friendly Toward U. S.

Squad of 40 Candidates Practicing Regularly in the Cage—Prospects for
Championship Twelve
Very Bright.

Dr. William H. Welch, dean of
the Johns Hopkins Medical School,
has just returned to Baltimore after a trip to China, which he undertook last summer as a representative of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Dr. Welch left on June 30. He
spent three weeks in the Hawaiian
Islands and five weeks in Yokohama, Japan; visited Pekin and
Moukton and went up the Yangtse
River beyond Hamktow.
The chief purpose of Dr. Welch's
expedition was to investigate medical education in China, and to introduce some of the medical ideas
of the Occidentals. As a result of
the visit, Dr. Welch will make extensive recommendations tending to
improve the medical ideas of the
country through the China Medical Board, of which he is a member.
The report to this board has not
as yet been made. Dr. Welch said
that the work to be taken in hand
immediately would be the enlarging
of the Union Medical School in
Pekin and the possible establishment
of another school, probably in
Shanghai.
Dr. Welch, when interviewed,
stated that the opportunities for
medical education in China are very
great, but that there are serious
drawbacks, such as the difficulties
met in locating the schools, lack of
funds wherewith to pay for the services of good doctors, and inability
to acquire good men without paying
good salaries.
•
Dr. Welch also expressed himself
in regard to the political situation
in China. He is of the opinion that
China is not so much of a republic
as a military despotism, and thinks
that the sentiment of the country
is apparently opposed to the republican form.
As regards the relations of the
United States with Japan, Dr.
Welch believes that there is nothing
which need at any time in the future cause a clash between the two
countries. At the same time, however, he stated that the Japanese are
a proud people, who are deter •
mined that they shall be accepted
on the same basis on which the
other great nations of the world are
accepted.
Now that Japan has been cut off
from its medical relations with Germany, Dr. Welch thinks many are
coming to this country to study
medicine. Moreover, the Japanese
have developed the study of medicine within their own land to such
a point that we are able to learn
from them.
This has been the first time since
his connection with Hopkins that
Dr. Welch has not been at the University for the opening of the academic year.

With the holiday season a thing
of the past, the lacrosse squad has
now settled down to the hard work
that is ahead in order to develop
a championship 1916 team.
Several practices were held in
the cage during the Christmas holidays. However, it is realized that
with only about two months left to
round out the team there is much
hard work ahead for the members
of the squad. Captain Paul Sutton especially emphasizes the need
of defensive material. The team
will be materially weakened in this
department this season through the
loss of John Huck. With this in
mind, the coaches are watching a
number of new men who are showing particularly good form for this
position.
Practices are now held daily.
Coach Rainey Wolfe heretofore has
been rather lax with the men in
regard to attendance, but now he
wants it known that it is imperative that all men who are out for
the team must report more regularly, especially on Wednesday and
Saturday, when the entire squad
works out in the cage.
Scrimmages are also a feature of
the practices. The squad is divided
into two teams, with the lineup
changed from time to time, in order
to give the men a better chance to
try out the various positions.
A contemplation of this season's
material shows prospects for a lacrosse team that will compare with
last year's championship team to
be very bright. The squad is composed of about forty men and contains ten of the twelve members ofthe 1915 team. The two players
who were lost are John Huck and
Toni Troxell, two of the best lacrosse players who ever represented
the Black and Blue. The coaches
realize that they have a hard task
before them in filling the places of
these former stars, but are relying
on last year's substitutes and a number of new players on the squad
who entered the University this
year from City College and Polytechnic Institute to fill the open
gaps.
Probably the most promising new
member of the squad is Arthur
Knipp, an uncle of Johnny Knipp,
who has returned to the University this year in order to take certain engineering courses. Some
years ago, Mr. Knipp was a star
member of Hopkins teams, playing
on the 'Varsity for three successive
years. He is still eligible by the
rules of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
League to play another year for the
Black and Blue.
The coaches also emphasize the
fact that although only two vacancies appear this year, there are at
all times twelve positions to be contested for, and the tiew men have

JUNIORS AND SENIORS HARD
AT WORK ON COMING DEBATE

Preparations for the inter-class
debate are being made by both the
Junior and Senior teams, and there
is every indication that the contest
of January 28 will be a hard-fought
and interesting one.
Owing to the fact that preparations for the 'Varsity triangle debates have not as yet been completed, the class debaters did no
work whatever previous to or during the Christmas holidays. The
men on both teams were anxious
to have the same subject for the
inter-class as for the University
debates in order that a great
deal of extra work might be saved
and the contests of next spring adequately prepared for. As further
delay is now impossible, however,
the work of preparation has been
activly entered upon, and Hopkins
is hoping that the question submitted by her council will meet
with the approval of Virginia and
North Carolina.
The subject of the Junior-Senior
debate, "Resolved, that for state legislatures a unicameral is preferable
to a bicameral system," is one that
has of late been discussed by many
writers on political subjects, and
that should prove of particular interest to the members of the first
undergraduate class in political science in the University.
Positions on the two teams were
not as closely contested this year as
is usually the case, owing to the fact
that the tryouts were held immediately before the Christmas examinations. The members of the Junior team, which will champion the
affirmative of the question, are A. A.
Steinbach, chairman; A. A. Weech
and Randolph Smith, while the Senior debaters are T. J. Tingley, chairman; G. Franklin Ludington and
Harrison C. Coffin. Mr. C. Whitford McDowell is the Senior alternate, while the Junior alternate and
advisors for both teams will be
chosen in the immediate future.

LECTURES ON "CITY PLANNING"

FIFTH REGIMENT MEET FEB. 12

Prof. Fairclough, of Stanford, Talks to
Archaeological Society on Building
of Ancient Cities of Rome.

Hotly Contested Races Expected—Meeting of Athletic Association Called to
Ratify Spring Schedule and
Arrange Meet.

The local society of the Archeological Institute of America held
its first meeting of the year on
January 3, in McCoy Hall, at which
time an illustrated lecture was given
by Prof. H. Rushton Fairclough,
formerly a director in the American
Academy at Rome and now a
member of the faculty of Stanford
University. Professor Faircloug-h's
topic, "City Planning in Ancient
Rome," was in a way a sequel to
his former lecture given here on
the three beautiful capitals of the
world—Athens, Rome and Washington.
"City planning," he said, "is not
a new development; the first public
basilica having been built in 185 B.
C., and the first arch in 121 B. C.
But though Rome had its forum
before the time of Cesar, the first
efforts toward a well-planned city
and civic center originated with
him. He sought to make the forum
more symmetrical and to enlarge it
for the demands which would be
placed upon it as the chief public
place of the imperial city. A walled
city in the midst of the activities of
the city proper, the forum was a
place set apart suitable for special
functions, where the orators spoke,
from which the emperors sent forth
the generals and governors of the
empire, and where many religious
celebrations were held.
"Cxsar also first attempted the
beautification of the Campus Martins and devoted himself to the construction of such massive public
structures as the Circus Maximus
and the Basilica Julia. The system
of parks and public places thus inaugurated was advanced by the succeeding emperors, notably Augustus, Vespasian, Nerva and Trajan."
Professor Fairclough closed his
lecture by calling attention to the
large part classical architecture has
played in America's model city of
the Panama-Pacific Exposition. Its
walled effect, with courts dominated
by a public building, is reminiscent
of the forums, while a number of
the palaces are reproductions of the
Roman Thermae. Much of the
charm of the exposition, indeed, was
due, he said, to the combination of
all the arts in the true classical
spirit.

28 E. BALTIMORE STREET

A meeting of the Athletic Association has been called for this afternoon at 5 o'clock, in the Trophy
Room. Among the most important
matters to be brought up during
the meeting will be the ratification
of the spring schedule and the completion of the plans for the Hopkins-Fifth Regiment track meet.
The Fifth Regiment meet is
scheduled to begin at 8 o'clock on
the evening of Saturday, February
12. This will be the eleventh annual track meet to be held under
the joint auspices of the Fifth
Regiment and the Johns Hopkins
University, and is certain to be hotly
contested. A number of very
brilliant relay races are promised
between teams representing some
of the biggest colleges in the country, as well as the Hopkins-Virginia
relay race, which is the main event
each year.
This meet has been arranged by
a joint committee composed of three
members from both the Fifth Regiment and the University, and which
has for its chairman Lieut.-Col.
Washington Bowie, Jr.
As has been the custom in past
years, undergraduate students will
act as ushers.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 10, 1915.
The Hullabaloo Benefit.

Friday night, January, 21, will be
the time for every Hopkins man to
do his part toward the publication
of the 1916 Hullabaloo.
The opinion seems to prevail
among under-classmen generally
that the Ht,illabaloo is the affair of
the Senior Class alone, that somehow
or other it is the business of two or
three editors to create, compile, finance and publish the book that is to
represent the entire University,.and
that is to be enjoyed by every
undergraduate. As a matter of fact,
every man at Hopkins ought to take
a personal interest in the Senior annual. It is not the record of the
accomplishments of the graduating
class alone: it is typical of the University as a whole. There is no
Hopkins activity, from football to
chess, that is not given its adequate
place and reCorded all due honor between its covers. The Hullabaloo is
typical of Hopkins life and of Hopkins men.
The Board this year has done
everything in its power to make the
book the best that has ever been
issued by a Hopkins graduating
class. They have secured the services of the ablest engravers in the

country, and the photographic work
is of the highest quality. Advance
indications are to the effect that the
1916 book will be the "best ever."
But the Board can only create a
good Hullabaloo; they can not make
it a success. That is the manifest
duty of every man at the University.
There is no reason why the Hopkins annual should not occupy a
position among • the best college
yearbooks published in the country.
It should be a matter of pride with
Hopkins men to make it occupy
such a position.
The 1916 benefit will be held Friday night, January 21, at Ford's.
Don't give up too early in your attempt to sell the Senior tickets. And
by all means be on hand Friday
night to make it a real Hopkins
night, and not a hopeless "flareback."
SENIORS ELECT DR. LATANE
HONORARY CLASS PRESIDENT

At a meeting of the Class of 1916,
held on Wednesday at i P. M., in
Room I I, Dr. John Holladay Latane, professor of history of the
University faculty, was elected honorary president of the seniors. A
large number of candidates were
nominated for the position, and
after some elimination, Dr. Latane
was chosen.
An address concerning the coming senior benefit at "Rolling
Stones," on the night of January
21, was made by Mr. McDowell,
the chairman of the benefit committee, who urged the members of the
class to do their best to make the
affair a success and so to insure.
the success of their Hullabaloo.
WORK ON CIVIL ENGINEERING
BUILDING WELL UNDER WAY

In spite of the bad weather, considerable progress has been made
on the new Civil Engineering Building at Homewood during the holidays. The excavation has been
completed and the concrete foundations and the lower brick walls
are now being laid.
The contract calls for the completion of the building by August 15,
and unless the winter is extremely
severe it should be finished on time.
The style of the new building will
be colonial, thus conforming with
the other structures. In appearance it will be very much like the
present Electrical and Mechanical
Building, which it will face. A
striking difference, however, will
be found in the part corresponding
to Machinery Hall and in the wings.
In their place a large lecture room
or auditorium will be built in the
center of the back. The remainder
of the building will closely follow
in general details the present one.

1915.

U. S. TO CONDUCT STUDENT CAMP
College Men Have Opportunity to Learn
Military Details at Low Cost at
Fort Oglethorpe, Ga.

A student camp, which will be
open to college students, will begin
its season at Fort Oglethorpe, Ga.,
on July 5, 1916. It will be conducted by the Eastern Department
of the United States Army.
Any student between the ages
of eighteen and thirty, who is five
feet four inches high, having eyesight normal or corrected by glasses
to admit of target practice, may, if
his application blank is accepted,
receive four weeks' training in the
camp in the fundamental education
of an officer, including rifle practice.
Special opportunities will be offered
for training in various branches of
the service—cavalry, artillery, engineers, signal corps and first aid.
The expense for the four weeks
will be thirty dollars and will completely cover board, camp expenses
and ammunition expended. The
student will also be expected to provide his clothing, which can be secured at camp the government
will furnish ordnance, blankets, etc.
The Young Men's Christian Association will provide tables, chairs,
washing material, etc.
Fort Oglethorpe is near Chattanooga, Tenn., and has large drill
grounds, running water, electric
lights and ample space in which
to store trunks and suitcases containing civilian clothes.
Application blanks and any information may be had by applyng to
"Officer in Charge, Southern Military Training Camp, Governors
Island, N. Y."
High Honor for Dr. Lovejoy.

Dr. A. 0: Lovejoy, of the University faculty of philosophy, was
recently elected president of the
American Philosophical Association.
Before he came to Hopkins, Dr.
Lovejoy was professor of philosophy at Leland Stanford and at the
University of Missouri. He has
done ninth important work on
eighteenth century philosophy, the
history of the theory of evolution,
relation of Kant's philosophy to the
earlier schools, and the idea of
energy in primitive religion and
magic.
Dr. Lovejoy was vice-president
of the society in 1909, and president
of the Western Philosophical Association in 19o8, but this is the first
time that a Hopkins man has had
the distinction of being president
of the American Philosophical Association.

That Boston Tea Party.

"Did I hear you say lemon ?"
purred the pouring bud.
"N-no, I never use slang," Horace replied, as he stepped on the foot
of a lady behind him.
"Cream, then ?" guessed the
hostess.
"Thank you—I beg your pardon
p-please excuse me—thank—" he
stammered, speaking before and behind at the same time. So she
gave him tea without cream. He
thought he had asked for cream, because he hated tea without it; but
what could he do? He took it, and
promptly flipped the spoon on the
floor: . She offered him another one,
but he insisted on retrieving his
own—to hide his confusion. He
stooped to pick it up, and poured
hot tea on a slender silk-clad ankle
in his efforts.
"Oh, I beg your—." As he got
up, his head hit the table. A pile
of sandwiches slid from the plate
to the carpet, cascading over his
neck. This was too much. He
staggered to his feet.
"Really, I do beg—." But she was
not looking at him. Thoroughly
routed, he grasped a cake, and
buried his thumb in the soft raspberry jam which capped it. Desperation seized him. He dragged
his handkerchief from his pocket;
as it came out, it was accompanied
by
